channel.title: Brahs... i got som gud nuwz
channel.description:
http://www.foxnews.com/health/2013/03/27/scientists-find-treatment-to-kill-every-kind-cancer-tumor/ http://www.nypost.com/p/news/international/every_cancer_kills_tumor_them_kind_L9lppJmy9gCoS848cSzqbP
One drug to rule them all: Researchers find treatment that kills every kind of cancer tumor By MICHAEL BLAUSTEIN Last Updated: 10:48 AM, March 27, 2013 Posted: 10:46 AM, March 27, 2013 Researchers might have found the Holy Grail in the war against cancer, a miracle drug that has killed every kind of cancer tumor it has come in contact with. The drug works by blocking a protein called CD47 that is essentially a "do not eat" signal to the body's immune system, according to Science Magazine. This protein is produced in healthy blood cells but researchers at Stanford University found that cancer cells produced an inordinate amount of the protein thus tricking the immune system into not destroying the harmful cells. With this observation in mind, the researchers built an antibody that blocked cancer's CD47 so that the body's immune system attacked the dangerous cells. So far, researchers have used the antibody in mice with human breast, ovary, colon, bladder, brain, liver and prostate tumors transplanted into them. In each of the cases the antibody forced the mice's immune system to kill the cancer cells. "We showed that even after the tumor has taken hold, the antibody can either cure the tumor or slow its growth and prevent metastasis," said biologist Irving Weissman of the Stanford University School of Medicine in Palo Alto, California. One side effect of the treatment was that healthy cells were subjected to short-term attacks by the mice's immune system, but the effect was nothing in comparison to the damage done to the cancer cells. Weissman's group recently received a $20 million dollar grant to move their research from mouse to human safety testing.

item.title: Brahs... i got som gud nuwz
item.dc:creator: @NewbieNewty Newty
item.description:
@NewbieNewty wrote:

This would be such an achievement if they can finally find a drug to defeat cancer! There is always going to be a disease that we are battling against but beating cancer would open up more money for development against the next big threat!

Here’s hoping!

Read full topic

item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

KroniKz_:

Wish this came sooner.

That’s really what everyone is thinking/saying. Just think about the people that are losing family to cancer, as this is being developed. It’s more of a “loss” to them because they were closer to the cure. But in a generalized idea, we all lost the same… (I lost a grandma to it)

item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:31, topic:511376”][quote author=Elrick link=topic=629621.msg4270919#msg4270919 date=1364521264]

How much worse can you get than cancer? I mean really unless something is going to kill you faster, I don’t know how much worse it can get.

That’s what we don’t know.

I know, I’m just saying that cancer seems to be pretty much as bad as you can get. It’s pretty damn painful and you die in a relatively short amount of time. Although, this could turn into I Am Legend. I suppose that might be worse…
[/quote]
A disease could form that could kill you in 48 hours or less. The thing is. Limitless amounts of diseases could form. We don’t know what to expect.[/quote]
And as I already said, one in a million, no, billion. But yes it is possible

item.title: Brahs... i got som gud nuwz
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“TabbyKiller, post:26, topic:511376”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=629621.msg4270871#msg4270871 date=1364519073]

Cures cancer and then an advanced plague comes back! That would be interesting…

Cancer can’t spread. Whoever started talking about super viruses is stupid.

You’re stupid.

If this goes forward to human testing then that’s a massive step in the battle against cancer. That’s some good news.

Just wait. After they cure cancer. A bigger, even more violent disease will emerge…

Yes, however based off of what you have that implies that the thing that cures cancer will morph into some dangerous disease. I’m sure there are plenty of diseases/illnesses that are worse then cancer that we have discovered, but that’s simply because we haven’t discovered them yet.

You’re taking something I said out of context, and them flipping it against me.

What reyx is saying, we’re sure that our scientist will check out every possibility of other diseases being developed before letting this ‘cure’ go public. A possible disease cannot just pop out of no where it would have to be something 1 out of a million, if you’ve seen the movie Contagion then this quote will arouse you, “The wrong pig met up with the wrong bat.”

Again. I’m not saying a disease will develop because of this cure. I’m saying one will be found. If it happens to come from this then, what ever. Just look at history and the cures we have to day.
Common cold
Flu
H1N1
etc.
They all killed (still do in third world countries, and rare cases in first world), but they have been ‘cured’.
Something worse came after each one though.
Plus. That was my opinion I stated. Arguing opinions is rather stupid…
[/quote]
I kind of see that as a pretty negative way of thinking about the situation we have with the cure for cancer, the only reason why the next disease would be found is because the biggest threat (cancer) is gone so we move on to finding the next best thing, discovered or undiscovered. Though I don’t much about biology but it takes one bad substrate to find one bad enzyme and boom, you’ll have a new disease, but the chances of that is one in a million, just like trying to fit a key into a million locks and just because cancer wouldn’t be around doesn’t mean that the disease would somehow just activate. The way you say it makes it seem that the diseases are all forming a line after each other.

I have done next to no research so how diseases develop is beyond me, I am just going off the common knowledge I have.[/quote]
I’m going off what I know too.
They “technically” go in a line, cause we do find one after the other, or during the research of it.
But most scientists aren’t looking for the next one, until one is solved. So say cancer is ‘solved’ they move on. and bang, they happen to find it

Read full topic
item.source: Brahs... i got som gud nuwz

item.title: Brahs... i got som gud nuwz
item.dc:creator: @TabbyKiller TabbyKiller
item.description:
@TabbyKiller wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:20, topic:511376”][quote author=TabbyKiller link=topic=629621.msg4270866#msg4270866 date=1364518426]

Cures cancer and then an advanced plague comes back! That would be interesting…

Cancer can’t spread. Whoever started talking about super viruses is stupid.

You’re stupid.

If this goes forward to human testing then that’s a massive step in the battle against cancer. That’s some good news.

Just wait. After they cure cancer. A bigger, even more violent disease will emerge…

Yes, however based off of what you have that implies that the thing that cures cancer will morph into some dangerous disease. I’m sure there are plenty of diseases/illnesses that are worse then cancer that we have discovered, but that’s simply because we haven’t discovered them yet.

You’re taking something I said out of context, and them flipping it against me.

What reyx is saying, we’re sure that our scientist will check out every possibility of other diseases being developed before letting this ‘cure’ go public. A possible disease cannot just pop out of no where it would have to be something 1 out of a million, if you’ve seen the movie Contagion then this quote will arouse you, “The wrong pig met up with the wrong bat.”

[/quote]
Again. I’m not saying a disease will develop because of this cure. I’m saying one will be found. If it happens to come from this then, what ever. Just look at history and the cures we have to day.
Common cold
Flu
H1N1
etc.
They all killed (still do in third world countries, and rare cases in first world), but they have been ‘cured’.
Something worse came after each one though.
Plus. That was my opinion I stated. Arguing opinions is rather stupid…[/quote]
I kind of see that as a pretty negative way of thinking about the situation we have with the cure for cancer, the only reason why the next disease would be found is because the biggest threat (cancer) is gone so we move on to finding the next best thing, discovered or undiscovered. Though I don’t much about biology but it takes one bad substrate to find one bad enzyme and boom, you’ll have a new disease, but the chances of that is one in a million, just like trying to fit a key into a million locks and just because cancer wouldn’t be around doesn’t mean that the disease would somehow just activate. The way you say it makes it seem that the diseases are all forming a line after each other, waiting for their turn.

I have done next to no research so how diseases develop is beyond me, I am just going off the common knowledge I have.

Read full topic

If this goes forward to human testing then that’s a massive step in the battle against cancer. That’s some good news.

Just wait. After they cure cancer. A bigger, even more violent disease will emerge…

Yes, however based off of what you have that implies that the thing that cures cancer will morph into some dangerous disease. I’m sure there are plenty of diseases/illnesses that are worse then cancer that we have discovered, but that’s simply because we haven’t discovered them yet.

What reyx is saying, we’re sure that our scientist will check out every possibility of other diseases being developed before letting this ‘cure’ go public. A possible disease cannot just pop out of no where it would have to be something 1 out of a million, if you’ve seen the movie Contagion then this quote will arouse you, “The wrong pig met up with the wrong bat.”

[/quote]
Again. I’m not saying a disease will develop because of this cure. I’m saying one will be found. If it happens to come from this then, what ever. Just look at history and the cures we have to day.
Common cold
Flu
H1N1
etc.
They all killed (still do in third world countries, and rare cases in first world), but they have been ‘cured’.
Something worse came after each one though.
Plus. That was my opinion I stated. Arguing opinions is rather stupid…[/quote]
That makes your statement completely irrelevant to the subject of curing cancer. Due to the fact that it has not been discovered, it could show up at any time, before or after we have a sufficient cure for cancer.
